direct_answer.text:
First, let's rewrite the double summation using index shifting. Letting $m=j+k$, our summation becomes
\[\sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{\substack{m \\ m > j}}^{\infty} \frac{1}{m^3}.\]We shift indices so each term includes both variables instead of just one variable; thus, letting $l=-j,$ giving us
\begin{align*}
&= -\sum_{l = -1}^{\infty} \sum_{k = l + 1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(l + k)^3}\\
&= -\sum_{l = 0}^{\infty} (-l)\left(\sum_{k = 1}^{-(l + 1)} \frac{1}{k^3}\right)\\
&= p \sum_{l = 0}^{\infty} \frac{-l}{(l + 1)^3}.
